The Bible never mentions abortion, not at all.  The closest verse is one on miscarriage:  Exodus 21:22  "When people who are fighting injure a pregnant woman so that there is a miscarriage, and yet no further harm follows, the one responsible shall be fined what the woman’s husband demands, paying as much as the judges determine. If any harm follows, then you shall give life for life, eye for eye, tooth for tooth, hand for hand, foot for foot, burn for burn, wound for wound, stripe for stripe.That would imply that killing the fetus is not considered equal to killing a person. Causing a miscarriage carries a financial penalty. Causing bodily harm to the woman carries a personal penalty (perhaps even their life). The Biblical theme seems to be that life begins with breath.  Genesis 2:7 “then the Lord God formed man from the dust of the ground, and breathed into his nostrils the breath of life; and the man became a living being.”Job 33:4 “The spirit of God has made me, and the breath of the Almighty gives me life”Ezekiel 37:5-6 “Thus says the Lord God to these bones:I will cause breath to enter you, and you shall live. I will lay sinews on you, and will cause flesh to come upon you, and cover you with skin, and put breath in you, and you shall live.”Acts 17:24 "nor is he served by human hands, as though he needed anything, since he himself gives to all mortals life and breath and all things."Revelation 11:11 But after the three and a half days, the breath of life from God entered them, and they stood on their feet, and those who saw them were terrified."Breath and spirit are both one word both in Hebrew and Greek. They are constantly brought together in Scripture as analogous. According to the Bible, life begins when the first breath is drawn. If a man hurts a woman, causing her to miscarry, the punishment is not the same as if a man murders another man. The punishment for murder is much different than the punishment for causing a miscarriage in the Bible.  Note that the Bible places no financial value on infants less than one month old. Leviticus 27:2-7 When a person makes an explicit vow to the Lord concerning the equivalent for a human being, the equivalent for a male shall be: from twenty to sixty years of age the equivalent shall be fifty shekels of silver by the sanctuary shekel. If the person is a female, the equivalent is thirty shekels. If the age is from five to twenty years of age, the equivalent is twenty shekels for a male and ten shekels for a female. If the age is from one month to five years, the equivalent for a male is five shekels of silver, and for a female the equivalent is three shekels of silver. And if the person is sixty years old or over, then the equivalent for a male is fifteen shekels, and for a female ten shekels."The verses used to argue that the fetus is human are almost entirely poetic verses that describe God’s knowledge and actions, not the soul or life of a fetus.  Jeremiah 1:5 “Before I formed you in the womb I knew you, and before you were born I consecrated you; I appointed you a prophet to the nations.”Psalms 139: "For it was you who formed my inward parts; you knit me together in my mother’s womb...My frame was not hidden from you, when I was being made in secret, intricately woven in the depths of the earth. Your eyes beheld my unformed substance. In your book were written all the days that were formed for me, when none of them as yet existed."Note that these are poems, e.g., “knitted together: “woven in the depths of the earth." They also talk about God knowing them BEFORE they were formed in the womb - before conception. Were they human before they were even conceived? No. These are poems about God’s knowledge and actions. I am afraid that there is no clear Biblical argument that abortion is murder.

There’s only one direct mention of abortion in the Bible: the ordeal of the bitter water, from Numbers 5:11–31. You can read it for yourself, but the basic idea is if a husband suspects his wife of infidelity, he can make her undergo a bizarre ritual which, if she was unfaithful, will result in a magic abortion. There’s a lot more that can be said on this topic, of course. One consistent theme in the Old Testament is that a fetus simply does not have the same value as a live human. For example, pregnant women were executed (e.g. Tamar in Genesis 38), and miscarriage is mentioned as a punishment (e.g. Hosea 9:14). But I’d like to talk for a moment about one of the most telling passages, which is this one: When people who are fighting injure a pregnant woman so that there is a miscarriage, and yet no further harm follows, the one responsible shall be fined what the woman’s husband demands, paying as much as the judges determine. Exodus 21:22 (NRSV) That’s possibly the clearest statement that under Old Testament law, a crime which causes a miscarriage is punished less harshly than one that kills a live person. It doesn’t get any more obvious than this. It’s so obvious, in fact, that some people in the United States, who want desperately to prove that abortion is the worst of all possible sins, have taken to rewriting the text of the Bible to make it mean something else for their own political ends. The weird thing is that it’s Protestants who seem to want to do this. One would think that rewriting the text of the Bible is the worst of all sins for Protestants, but apparently not when there are higher cynical political values at stake. All American Evangelical Protestant translations of the Bible produced in the United States since the late 70s (only American ones and only Evangelical Protestant ones; even the standard Catholic translation, the New Jerusalem Bible, is not affected by this revisionism) translate this as “give birth prematurely” and relegate “miscarriage” to a footnote. There’s one exception: the latest Southern Baptist translation, the CSB, keeps the historically incorrect reading and drops the footnote. The New Testament says essentially nothing, which makes sense because unlike the Mosaic law, the New Testament is not the legal code of a nation. Christianity was not designed to be “in charge”, so is far less prescriptive on anything except personal holiness. So to answer your question: The Bible explicitly provides for (and gives a recipe for) abortion in one instance. Elsewhere, it doesn’t say much, but to the extent that there is a clear and consistent message, it’s that a fetus is important and valued, but is not legally or morally the same as a live human. To quote Norman Geisler’s Ethics: Alternatives and Issues (circa 1975, before American Evangelicalism was infected by post-Watergate politics), “abortion is less serious than murder” and “abortion is more serious than birth control”. For a Christian moral philosopher, that’s the source material, but obviously in the light of modern medical science it doesn’t stop there. Those are the principles from which to come to a conclusion.

As others have already pointed out the Bible doesn't specifically address abortion. But it speaks a great deal about human life and as Stephen Frantz points out even places various monetary values on people of different ages and genders. Some how I think that was done because of the hardness of the hearts of man. The Gospel of Jesus Christ gives us a much deeper insight on Just how much God values us. So much so that He gave up divine privilege so He could walk among us and call us friends, Paul says He bankrupted Heaven when he presented Himself a living sacrifice and all of that so He could save us and redeem us back to Himself. Even the Law itself was designed for us, Jesus testifying that the Sabbath was made for man, not man for the Sabbath. Can we also say that, thou shalt not kill has this same quality.  So then the question is when does a human life begin? The writer of Hebrews says that Isaac was in the loins of Abraham and so paid tithes to Melchizedek years before Isaac was born. Can we look at that and say that even I was in the loins of Adam or Noah. And that the premature death of anyone at all also cuts off future generations. Perhaps; but I am not sure I want to take such a stand.  I will take this stand however; for I believe that God takes a role and personal interest in the development of every fetus. Jeremiah stating that God knew him in the womb and called him to be a prophet. Paul saying that He was set apart even in his mother womb, John the Baptist leaping at the News of Jesus conception in the womb of Elizabeth at six months pregnant, and certainly the miracle of Jesus conception Himself are indicators that God regards the womb a holy place, and the lives in them as viable.

Yes, the Bible supports abortion, because people are not considered “alive” until they take their first breath: “Then the Lord God formed a man from the dust of the ground and breathed into his nostrils the breath of life, and the man became a living being.” Genesis 2:7 Jeremiah 1:5, "Before I formed you in the womb I knew you, before you were born I set you apart; I appointed you as a prophet to the nations” is often quoted as support for life beginning at conception, however, a little analysis will show that this isn’t what the verse is saying. It only says that God knew who we were before we existed; it says nothing about when life begins. The argument over abortion is a relatively recent one. The Catholic Church has opposed abortion since the 17th century, in an effort to ensure that Catholics would outnumber Protestants. In the U.S., few Protestants opposed abortion until the late 1970s, when agitators like Jerry Falwell began using legal abortion and gay rights as rallying points in the “culture war.” Until then, it wasn’t unusual for a Republican like George H.W. Bush to be pro-choice, or a conservative Democrat like Al Gore Jr. to be pro-life. Today, the abortion debate is almost unanimously polarized between the two parties.

Original Question: “Does the Bible support abortion?” Yes. Absolutely. First commandment out of the box: “I am the Lord, thy God and you shall have no other gods before me.” Taking the body of work of the Bible as a whole, God and possibly those prohibited or subordinated lower-case gods are distinguished from humanity by both omniscience about the future and capacity to influence, to morph future events beyond all our efforts at comprehension of rules of causation. God does miracles. God makes choices that mess with human plans beyond their understanding. Minor gods may dabble in this, too. Whether this little tidbit is truth is still a little sketchy. The point is, human trespass into the business of God, and maybe lesser gods, saints and angels, is elevation of the human into god-turf. Action above pay grade. Way over pay grade. Given that we cannot know God’s will in advance, we cannot comprehend it until it smites or saves us, it follows that: Any and all Human presumption of the future is an audacious trespass and violation of the very first sentence etched on Moses’s tablets. Prenatal gestation is a perilous time for male-dominated societies. In the Bronze Age, the most fragile interval for a monarch, or anyone with any power or stored wealth, was when their significant woman was “with child”. Any time after birth, Regicide can be thwarted. Loyal guards can be posted. Plots rooted out and foiled. Bad actors, beheaded or exiled. Not so, when the queen is with child. Yet the human condition is not that of the gods. We are of the animals. We make babies in a woman’s womb. To understand the anti-abortion argument, we must recognize both the rejection of our actual humanity: a mammal that relies on live birth after gestation in a woman’s womb; and, rejection of the very first commandment. Trespass of anyone on the individual integrity of body of another, with purpose to subordinate that other person to one’s wishes and hopes which are ultimately beyond one’s control and knowledge is to act as a god ahead of, and before “The” God contrary to the first commandment. Most of recorded history and the subordination of women, the shunting of them into the broad category of property can be explained as desperate grasps at control of that which is beyond control. Prohibiting or even impeding abortion is telling God you know the future. You know His will. It is placing oneself or the State above God, in sorting out the eventuality. Commandments be damned.

The Bible does not directly address abortion, but it does speak directly regarding God's view of human life, including life within the womb. From these references we can develop a clear Christian worldview regarding the modern issue of abortion. The Bible says humans are made in the image of God: "Then God said, 'Let us make man in our image, after our likeness.' . . . So God created man in his own image, in the image of God he created him; male and female he created them" (Genesis 1:26-27). All human life is considered sacred and created by God. During the time of Moses, God gave laws for how Israel was to be governed. Some of those laws specified penalties for different crimes. In Exodus 21:22-25, the penalty for causing the death of an unborn child was "life for life." In other words, God saw killing a child in the womb as murder. These verses support the view that preborn infants are humans equal in importance to other people. Psalm 139:13-16 is a poetic description of life in the womb: "For you formed my inward parts; you knitted me together in my mother's womb. I praise you, for I am fearfully and wonderfully made. Wonderful are your works; my soul knows it very well. My frame was not hidden from you, when I was being made in secret, intricately woven in the depths of the earth. Your eyes saw my unformed substance; in your book were written, every one of them, the days that were formed for me, when as yet there was none of them." Here again, life in the womb is described as God's creation and therefore of tremendous worth. In Jeremiah 1:5 God says, "Before I formed you in the womb I knew you, and before you were born I consecrated you; I appointed you a prophet to the nations." Even before Jeremiah's birth, God had formed the prophet on purpose, for a purpose. Life in the womb is also affirmed in the story of Jesus' nativity. Mary the mother of Jesus traveled to visit her relative Elizabeth, who was also pregnant. "When Elizabeth heard the greeting of Mary, the baby leaped in her womb. And Elizabeth was filled with the Holy Spirit, and she exclaimed with a loud cry, 'Blessed are you among women! . . . Behold, when the sound of your greeting came to my ears, the baby in my womb leaped for joy'" (Luke 1:41-44). The Greek word translated "baby" in reference to the child inside Elizabeth's womb is the same word used for an infant outside of the womb. The preborn Jesus is also referred to as a "baby," a living human being. This is more than an emotional outburst from Elizabeth; she was "filled with the Holy Spirit" when she made the statement. The consensus of Scripture is that a baby in the womb is a unique human life. Therefore, children in the womb should be respected and protected. The Bible has much to say about defending the cause of the weak, especially those who have no voice. "Open your mouth for the mute, for the rights of all who are destitute" (Proverbs 31:8; see also Psalm 82:3). We bear the responsibility to speak for those who cannot speak for themselves, including children in the womb. Abortion - What does the Bible have to say?Another insightful passage from the Old Testament is found in Exodus 21:22-25. This passage describes what action is to be taken in a case of accidental injury to a pregnant woman: If men fight, and hurt a woman with child, so that she gives birth prematurely, yet no lasting harm follows, he shall surely be punished accordingly as the woman’s husband imposes on him; and he shall pay as the judges determine. But if any lasting harm follows, then you shall give life for life, eye for eye, tooth for tooth, hand for hand, foot for foot, burn for burn, wound for wound, stripe for stripe (NKJV). This passage has been mistranslated in some versions. For example, some versions use the word “miscarriage” instead of translating the Hebrew phrase literally—“so that her children come out.” The text is envisioning a situation in which two brawling men accidentally injure a pregnant bystander. The injury causes the woman to go into early labor, resulting in a premature birth of her child. If neither the woman nor the child is harmed, then the Law of Moses levied a fine against the one who caused the premature birth. But if injury or even death resulted from the brawl, then the law imposed a parallel punishment: if the premature baby died, the one who caused the premature birth was to be executed—life for life. This passage clearly considers the pre-born infant to be a human being, and to cause a pre-born infant’s death was homicide under the Old Testament—homicide punishable by death. Notice that this regulation under the Law of Moses had to do with injury inflicted accidentally. Abortion is a deliberate, purposeful termination of a child’s life. If God dealt severely with the accidental death of a pre-born infant, how do you suppose He feels about the deliberate murder of the unborn by an abortion doctor? The Bible states explicitly how He feels: “[D]o not kill the innocent and righteous. For I will not justify the wicked” (Exodus 23:7). As a matter of fact, one of the things that God hates is “hands that shed innocent blood” (Proverbs 6:17). Abortion and the BibleLeviticus 27:2-7  In order for people to free themselves or their family from a vow of service to God they were required to give to the sanctuary what amounts to a redemption price based on a person's gender and age. The value is not based on sex or age discrimination, as is sometimes thought, but on a person's physical strength. In other words, the valuation is not tied to a person's dignity or worth. The highest value is on a male aged between twenty and sixty. A female in the same bracket is judged to be of less value in terms of the work she could do, such as lifting the heavy carcasses of animals slain in sacrifice and disposing of their remains. It is a factor recognized in the athletic and sporting world that a man is, generally speaking, stronger than a woman. For this reason men and women do not compete against each other, otherwise the men would have an unfair advantage. People over sixty and children under five are also valued at a lower rate and males and females between the ages of five and twenty are also considered separately. The Factory Acts that came about in Britain in the wake of the Evangelical Revival of the eighteenth century sought in some way to recognize the different strengths and powers of the sexes, as well as of old people and children. For instance, they legislated against women and children labouring in the coalmines and other such places of work. Buying oneself out of the commitment was a costly business, for it is estimated that on average a person only earned about one shekel a month. It would therefore cost nearly a whole year's wages to redeem a male in the prime of life. For those who were too poor to pay such a valuation, the priest was given the power to set a value according to the person's ability to pay. It is assumed that the valuations were deliberately set high to discourage rash vows involving people. Philip H. Actually it's a matter of retrofitting the scriptures to the current beliefs of the religion. Every religion has this problem, because every religion morphs over time, making its scriptures progressively more and more anachronistic. A lot just gets swept under the rug, such as the Christian Bible's support for polygamy. Other things--such as abortion--become the recipients of truly impressive mental gymnastics that would have astonished the people who wrote and read the Bible originally. The things the writers of the Bible wanted to prescribe and proscribe, it prescribed and proscribed. It didn't leave it up to the reader to winkle out heretofore hidden meanings. The Bible--like most religions' sacred scriptures--isn't obscurantist or arcane. Religious scriptures tell you what to do and what to not do, based on the religious authority of those scriptures.  They don't beat around the bush.  But they do say what they mean and mean what they say in the language of the day and the context of the times.  Which were radically different 2,000 years ago.  Stephen Frantz's answer politely dissects the arguments made to try to bridge the chasm between what was said and thought then vs. what is said and thought now on this topic. Note that the now-t0-them-obvious opposition to abortion in the Bible was invisible to most Protestants until the 1970's. It had also been invisible to the Catholics until some 19th century Pope, responding to the scientific findings of the day, took it into his head to think that abortion was wrong. This belief got proselytized to Protestants in America in the 1970s under the direction of Republican operatives, who saw abortion as a wedge issue they could use to pry socially conservative Democrats away from that party to the GOP--which turned out to be true.  The Not-So-Lofty Origins of the Evangelical Pro-Life Movement One of the best circumstantial proofs of this is the fact that those who seek to criminalize abortion never try to make it a crime for the woman to get an abortion--only for the doctor to perform it. But if abortion is murder, the primary criminal is the person soliciting it; the doctor is only her hireling. Yet anti-abortion fanatics never stalk and gun down women who get abortions--only the doctors. This is sexist--and a sign of how fundamentally political the movement is, rather than principled. So anti-abortionism is at its essence political Christianity, based on ideas foreign to the authors and readers of the Bible 2,000 years ago.

Verses of Scripture that reference this are:  Galatians 5:19-21 - Now the works of the flesh are plain: fornication, impurity, licentiousness, idolatry, sorcery [pharmakeia], enmity, strife, jealousy, anger, selfishness, dissension, party spirit, envy, drunkenness, carousing, and the like. The Bible does not mention abortion per se but does mention the duty owed to other human beings. I would therefore rephrase this question to whether or not the Bible regards the human fetus as a human person. The Bible refers to human life in the womb on numerous occasions. • In Genesis 25:21-22, we see that Rebekah's "children jostled each other in the womb." The Bible refers to the twin boys developing in Rebekah's womb as children. The Lord heard his entreaty, and his wife Rebekah became pregnant. But the children jostled each other in the womb so much that she exclaimed, “If it is like this, why go on living!” (Gen. 25:21–22, Bible Gateway passage: Genesis 25:21-22 - New American Bible (Revised Edition)) • In Tobit 4:3–4, Tobit gives his son Tobiah the following advice: Son, when I die, give me a decent burial. Honor your mother, and do not abandon her as long as she lives. Do whatever pleases her, and do not grieve her spirit in any way. Remember, son, how she went through many dangers for you while you were in her womb. When she dies, bury her in the same grave with me. (Tob. 4:3–5, Bible Gateway passage: Tobit 4:3-5 - New American Bible (Revised Edition)) Tobit refers to his son "while you were in her womb," which does not make sense unless Tobit's humanity began in the womb. • In 2 Maccabees 7:22–23, a mother tells her sons: I do not know how you came to be in my womb; it was not I who gave you breath and life, nor was it I who arranged the elements you are made of. Therefore, since it is the Creator of the universe who shaped the beginning of humankind and brought about the origin of everything, he, in his mercy, will give you back both breath and life, because you now disregard yourselves for the sake of his law. (2 Mac. 7:22–23, Bible Gateway passage: 2 Maccabees 7 - New American Bible (Revised Edition)) • God fashions human life in the womb, according to 2 Maccabees, and also Job 31:15: Did not he who made me in the belly make him? Did not the same One fashion us in the womb?
